etymologies: early 17th century; earliest use found in Henry Cockeram (fl. 1623–1658), lexicographer. From classical Latin percontatiōn-, percontatiō action of questioning, particular question from percontāt-, past participial stem of percontārī (also percontāre) to inquire, interrogate (from per- + contus boat-pole) + -iō

definitions: A question or inquiry which requires more than a ‘yes’ or ‘no’ answer.
